review.title: Annotated English
review.abstract: This document presents Annotated English, a system of diacritical symbols which turns English pronunciation into a precise and unambiguous process. The annotations are defined and located in such a way that the original English text is not altered (not even a letter), thus allowing for a consistent reading and learning of the English language with and without annotations. The annotations are based on a set of general rules that make the frequency of annotations not dramatically high. This makes the reader easily associate annotations with exceptions, and makes it possible to shape, internalise and consolidate some rules for the English language which otherwise are weakened by the enormous amount of exceptions in English pronunciation. The advantages of this annotation system are manifold. Any existing text can be annotated without a significant increase in size. This means that we can get an annotated version of any document or book with the same number of pages and fontsize. Since no letter is affected, the text can be perfectly read by a person who does not know the annotation rules, since annotations can be simply ignored. The annotations are based on a set of rules which can be progressively learned and recognised, even in cases where the reader has no access or time to read the rules. This means that a reader can understand most of the annotations after reading a few pages of Annotated English, and can take advantage from that knowledge for any other annotated document she may read in the future.

sections.heading: A Appendix. Alternative Rules and Additional Symbols
sections.text: In this appendix, we discuss some rules that could be included or excluded, and we also comment on the reasons why we ultimately made the decision to exclude or include them. This appendix is only recommended for people who want to find explanations for some of the decisions or want to open a discussion about some of the rules.

sections.heading: A.1 The n Most Common Words
sections.text: A very effective method of reducing annotations is to insert the n most common words into the pronunciation (interpretation) rules. We oppose this option in principle, as the good thing about annotations on common words is that they help to learn the pronunciation of other, less common words with the same annotation.The five most common words according to [5] are, for example: (the, from, to, and, a. sections.heading: A.2 The ed/es Rule
sections.text: The ed / es rule could be removed, simplified or extended, for example, to the regular case where "ed" and "es" [Id] and [Iz] are pronounced, which is contained in the rules of past participatory building and plural building. For example, "struck" and "bridges" would remain uncommented on. We did not take this into account (though speakers are well aware of it) because we want to emphasize the distinction between "loaves of bread" and "stuffed" and "struck" and "stuffed." Another problem might be to turn "ed" into "t" when preceded by a voiceless consonant group (to avoid the comment in "stuffed"), which would be consistent with what we do with the "s," where we do not need comments on "loaves" and "rats," although the "s" is pronounced and wordless "is respectfully expressed, but we present the combination here is more consistent for the discussion.

sections.heading: A.3 The Rules for Natural and Plain Positions

Words such as "be" and "go" would be considered natural positions, for example, but "plane," "code," etc. would be considered simple positions, which requires a note. Although this is contrary to traditional English spelling and pronunciation rules, it is competitive in terms of annotations. sections.heading: A.4 The Pronunciation of ‘s’ after a Vowel
sections.text: The rule for "s" understands this letter as one that oscillates between [s] and [z]. For the [z] sound, we have "z," and for the [s] sound, we have "ce," "ci," "ss." Therefore, "s" is considered a transitional consonant that has both sounds depending on the context, including other words nearby (such as "this is bad" or "this is terrible"). Our rules try to accommodate the spoken sound between vowels in ordinary words ("this," "light," "cause," "music" etc.) and also at the end of the word after a vowel or a spoken consonant ("like," "" is "and many plurals). Our first idea was to create combinations, such as in" backgro-u-nd, "" no-w, "" ta-u, "" La-o-s, "etc. But phonologically this is not true. So we considered introducing a new symbol for diphthongs, as follows: Wide diphthong. Single letter letter (" dip-a "): one. Double letter (" ddip-ae "): Áae. Previously it was like this: (" dip-i "): (" dip-i "). Examples: Background diphthongs (better described as background image): a double letter (" ddip-ae "): Áae.

sections.heading: A.8 The wa-, qua-, wo- Rule
sections.text: The sound for "want," was, "qua," etc., is so frequent that it might suggest a rule, but the variety of sounds (water, whales, whales, wall, distress, war, goods, wallet, wandering) makes it somehow impractical. In any case, it should be merged with the Qua rule (quantity, quarrel, but quark, quarter, quake), so that one would consider the "wa" combination. The rule would be (as a two-vowel unit), such as this: - "wa in clear position" (w6): want what, what, observe, wade, wade, wallet, wander, wallaby, warrior, quality, squatter (exception: whack, w-ater, wall, wax, wax, wagon) - "wa in natural position (or with other vowels): waby, waby, warrior, quality, squatter (exception: whack, wax, wax, or other)

sections.heading: A.9 The -al- / -all, -ol / -oll Rule
sections.text: The sounds for "a" and "o" before "l" are typically influenced in a systematic way. Again, a multitude of sounds make it impractical: all, wall, call, walk, talk, wallet, wallet, change, allies, algae, shall. In any case, the rule could also include the -ol- / -oll rule (control, roll, cold, bold, fold, sold, gold, told, poll), which is often natural and not plain), but (doll, follow, holly, alcohol,...).

sections.heading: A.10 The -ing- Rule
sections.text: It would be useful in many cases to consider this rule as a block to avoid divisions in the areas of "gaffes," "gaffes," "aging," etc., which do not occur because of "gaffes," "gaffes," etc. However, we would have some exceptions: Laing, Boing (both with diphthong before gaffes), bragging (vain, glorious), and we would have problems with "tiring" (tiring, gaffes) or "bilingual" (bil, ing, ual), depending on the order of the rules. Perhaps we would also have problems with "gaffes" and similar words. It would also cause confusion with "dot," "joint." If we leave it as we have done, it helps to avoid a typical confusion for foreigners to read "gaffes" as "gaffes."

sections.heading: A.11 The gu- Rule
sections.text: An alternative would be to consider the "u" (after "g") as quiet in any case. It would be good for "gu ‰ est," "gu ‰ ilt," "vogue," "guard" and "gu ‰ garantee." Another option would be to consider the u as w in any case. It would help for "penguin," "distinguish" etc. Finally, given the frequency, the similarity with the rules -ce, -ci and -ge, -gi, we decided to distinguish "gue" and "gui" from the rest.

sections.text: The reason for this is that this happens (almost always) on the left, but only sometimes on the right (and this depends on the dialect as the word "territory"). The connection with the sounds "", "", "", "", "", "" "is certainly innovative, but almost always true. There are other possible rules, such as that the primary voltage is always on the second vowel unit from the right when the word ends with a" c, "such as" automatic. "But we should consider other suffixes such as" ical, "" isis, "etc. Separators are a delicate thing. Separators that affect stress imply many things at the same time. They can be practical, but they can also be difficult to understand.

sections.text: The problem occurs when the same letter could have different sounds depending on the speed or emphasis of the reader. For example, emission and omission can sound different for many dialects if they are pronounced carefully, but they are indistinct in some dialects if they are read quickly. B.2 Manual Installation of Packages
sections.text: The "extraipa" package is not by default, so it needs to be installed manually. Mathabx fonts can be found here: http: / / www.ctan.org / tex-archive / fonts / mathabx / We need to download and extract mathabx.zip from there. In this document, there are: - 54 files in a folder called "source"; all 54 of these files had the extension.mf; - 4 files in a folder called "texinputs": mathabx.dcl, mathabx.sty, mathabx.tex, testmac.tex - Other 4 files outside of these folders. You can ignore them. Then the installation depends on the LATEX system you are using. Here I will describe this for MIKTEX for Windows, but it is similar for other distributions. Go to where your miktex distribution is located, and then look for the.abtex folder.

metadata.abstractText: This document presents _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^, a system of diacritical symbols which turns English pronunciation into a precise and unambiguous process. The annotations are defined and located in such a way that the original English text is not altered (not even a letter), thus allowing for a consistent reading and learning of the English language with and without annotations. The annotations are based on a set of general rules that makes the frequency of annotations not dramatically high (despite the chaotic orthography of English). This makes the reader easily associate annotations with exceptions, and makes it possible to shape, internalise and consolidate some rules for the English language which otherwise are weakened by the enormous amount of exceptions in English pronunciation. The advantages of this annotation system are manifold. Any existing text can be annotated without a significant increase in size. This means that we can get an annotated version of any document or book with the same number of pages and fontsize. Since no letter is affected, the text can be perfectly read by a person who does not know the annotation rules, since annotations can be simply ignored. The annotations are based on a set of rules which can be progressively learned and recognised, even in cases where the reader has no access or time to read the rules. This means that a reader can understand most of the annotations after reading a few pages of _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^, and can take advantage from that knowledge for any other annotated document she may read in the future. These features pave the way for multiple applications. _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^ can be used as a tool for teachers and parents when English-speaking children learn English orthography or simply when they start reading. Annotated textbooks, tales, dictionaries and any other material can make English orthography less painful. _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^ can also be very useful for students of English as a foreign language, since pronunciation is terribly troublesome for them, because they need to learn the meaning, the spelling and the pronunciation for each word they learn, and the pronunciation does not improve at all by reading. This is so because we can only see the spelling and infer the meaning, but books do not provide the correct pronunciation for each word. In fact, incorrect pronunciation (we are not referring here to a bad accent or intonation) persists in people who has lived in an English-speaking country for decades, because the true pronunciation is never shown (unless the IPA transcription is looked up in a dictionary), just heard in different contexts and situations. Finally, _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^ can also be very practical for any regular user (native or not) of the English language, very especially when facing new (especially technical) words and they have doubts about their pronunciation. In this document we introduce the rules for annotations and its symbols. This document is not intended for a general audience, and the explanations are focussed to precisely understand how the annotation system works. It is obvious that if the system has to be explained to a final user, a shorter and simpler manual should be issued for that. In any case, for learning _Annota " tėd Ėnglish^, the best thing is to take a look at the examples. There is a section in this document with some annotated texts. It is recommended to take a quick look at them before getting into details.
